ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of anatomical names

I gained a lot of knowledge about the anatomy of vertebrates such as sharks, salamanders, cats, sheep, lampreys, and. more. A major insight I developed during EEB 291L was how different anatomical structures evolved over time and how many taxa still share homologous parts as evidence of this evolution.

I learned how to identify different organs, bones, and muscle tissue across a variety of species. This information was then used to understand the evolutionary processes that allowed for these things to develop.

We learnt about vertebrates anatomy, focusing on a few clades and studying each system in depth. The lab was paired with the 290 lecture but we learnt all the necessary information in the lab lectures so it is possible to take the lab without the lecture
I think that I was able to learn better time management due to this lab. The lab reports were very time consuming so I had to plan my time well.

Strongly develops skills in comparative anatomy and physiology

Minorly develops skill in dissection
Learned about comparative developmental anatomy by watching dissection videos and doing virtual dissections
I learned about the body systems from an evolutionary perspective. we often compared animals across taxa, includes cartilaginous fish, bony fish, amphibians, mammals including humans.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Dr. Evans is very knowledgeable and passionate about comparative anatomy and it definitely shows through her teaching style. I really enjoyed her lectures and she presents information in a clear and concise manner. She's also very kind and understanding - the biggest strength of this course.
Weakness: For lab reports, I feel as though I got most of my information from outside sources and felt as though the materials provided by the instructors were not sufficient enough to complete the lab reports.

Overall, I feel the class was very well taught and did a good job of adapting to COVID. However, I feel like some key information was left out that could have assisted with the labs, such as the relationship between muscles and respiration in amphibians.
I think given the circumstances of online learning it was as best as could be.

Being a virtual lab its definitely not as engaging as an in person lab but I thought it really exceeded my expectations. I thought Id was well organised, there were clear expectations and I felt prepared for exams. I would have preferred to use the visible body software more since buying it was required and this would put more focus on the human systems (especially for premeds) or alternatively not use it at all since we already had one main mammal system (cat). It was a bit difficult to stay engaged with the early lectures when we were just drawing microscope slides so I would suggest condensing those into fewer labs if possible.

The "lecture" content for this class was very thorough and engaging. 
The course could be improved with greater feedback (whether personal or for the class overall) over the submissions.

Strengths: Very organized lectures, filled in a lot of gaps from anatomy lecture course, virtual dissections were fun
Weaknesses: Video dissections could be unclear at times, can't replicate in-person dissections

The professor Dr. Evans was really great. Very nice, engaging, smart, answers all of my questions. The pre-lab lectures were very concise and clear.
The first couple labs were not as interesting because of the format of looking at images/3D scans and just drawing and labelling. I thought histology and microscopy could have been cut in favor of learning the digestive system, but the class got more interesting as we went.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Posting pre-lab lectures in the media library was the best possible practice because it allowed for flexibility and meant I could watch the lectures at my availability instead of being tied to my computer every Thursday. The overall flexibility of the course was the greatest success, and I was very grateful for the chance to have a week to complete lab reports and watch the videos in my own time.
Everything was pretty good. My only complaint is that tests had us identify certain body parts from images and it wasn't always clear what we were being asked to identify.

I thought the time after lecture when we could work on activities/lab reports and ask questions was really useful, but I appreciated that it wasnt mandatory for every week. I also found the synchronous lectures useful. The dissection videos and 3D models were really good
I think the lab style overall worked pretty well. We had a 30 minute live lecture on Zoom, then we could log off and work on the lab ourselves. I personally preferred things this way.
The visible body courseware was definitely fun to work with and to learn from, though of course, nothing can really beat in-person dissections.

Virtual dissection application was useful but only for human body
Video dissections covered most things but still weren't as clear as in-person dissection could be

I thought the video dissections were really clear and good because we could watch and pause at our own pace. I would have liked if instead of a separate links document, the links were all embedded in the one lab instructions document. In general, would have been nice if all resources were consolidated, honestly would have preferred a recommended textbook because often felt like I was searching in many places for information. Loved the pre-lab lectures, very helpful. TAs were very responsive.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If it's required for the major, yes. It wasn't bad and could be really interesting at times. If it's not required, maybe not. The lab reports took a while because you have to do a lot of outside research for them.
Yes, it was very interesting and engaging. If you like evolutionary bio, this course is a great way to understand evolution of form and function.

Yes. Most people who take the lab will probably need to for a major requirement but I found the information actually really interesting and it was presented in a more digestible way than the 290 lecture. I would definitely recommend it for someone looking for a biology lab because all the information you need is presented in the lab lectures without needing to take 290 at the same time. The focus on vertebrates also makes it feel more relevant than a general ecology/EEB lab especially for a premed student
I think for students that are majoring in EEB, I would recommend the course to them as it is a major requirement. For those who are not, I would not recommend it.
Highly recommend; critical to even non-E&EB premed students
Yes, it was a good companion course to E&EB 290

Yes, it is a hefty time commitment because sometimes you don't finish the lab during the lab section and you have to finish it on your own AND do the lab report. But later, when the lab reports were just one or two written answers, you get the hang of the assignment and it doesn't take as long + you learn more. Great professor, if it's taught by Dr. Evans I would recommend this course. She makes the course well-organized and is a really clear instructor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live + recorded pre-lab lectures combined with posted videos of various dissections and provided u with other materials (youtube videos, websites, textbook excerpts)
There was an initial live virtual lecture that we were required to attend. The lab portion of the class could be completed anytime between then and the day of the next class.
in person lecture and recorded dissections
Live and recorded lecture and then optional time to complete lab activities synchronously and ask questions
